output.conclusion: This course provides an advanced understanding of machine design principles, enabling engineers to create robust and efficient mechanical systems.
output.introduction: Welcome to Advanced Machine Design! This course delves into the intricacies of designing complex mechanical systems, focusing on advanced analysis techniques and optimization strategies.

chapters.description: In-depth analysis of stress concentration factors, residual stresses, and their impact on component life.
Detailed examination of various failure theories, including distortion energy theory, maximum shear stress theory, and modified Mohr theory.
Advanced concepts in fatigue analysis, including S-N curves, fatigue life prediction, and crack growth analysis.
Techniques for modifying surface properties to enhance wear resistance, corrosion resistance, and fatigue life.
Study of friction, wear, and lubrication in mechanical systems, including hydrodynamic and elastohydrodynamic lubrication.
Advanced design considerations for rolling element bearings and journal bearings, including load distribution and lubrication.
Advanced gear design principles, including helical gears, bevel gears, and worm gears, with a focus on stress analysis and optimization.
Detailed analysis of shaft design, including stress concentration, fatigue, and critical speed calculations.
Design and selection of various types of couplings, including rigid couplings, flexible couplings, and fluid couplings.
Application of FEA to machine design problems, including stress analysis, thermal analysis, and vibration analysis.
Introduction to optimization techniques for machine design, including gradient-based methods and genetic algorithms.
Principles of DFM, including material selection, manufacturing processes, and assembly considerations.
